paragraphs.text: The Marinid dynasty, originating from the Zab region in Ifriqiya, established themselves in the central Maghrib plains . They were a Berber dynasty who rose to power after attacking an Almohad convoy around 1145 . By 1269, Abu Yusuf invested Marrakech and was proclaimed sultan, marking the beginning of their rule in the Maghrib until 1465 . The Marinids' rise coincided with the decline of the Almohad empire, which led to the emergence of three states: Ifriqiya, the extreme Maghreb (Marinids), and the central Maghreb, controlled by the Abd al-Wadid dynasty . The Abd al-Wadids, a Zenata tribe, established an independent dynasty in the central Maghreb, with Tlemcen as their capital . The Banu Abd al-Wad were part of the Zanata Berber tribe and shared nomadic origins with the Marinids . The Marinids, initially nomadic, expanded their power by incorporating Zanata from central Maghreb and Arab troops into their armies, supplementing them with mercenaries . The Marinids' expansionist ambitions brought them into direct conflict with the Abd al-Wadids of Tlemcen . The Abd al-Wadid dynasty's history involved a double relationship: with the Almohad caliphate in the 13th century and the Marinids from the 14th century onward .

sections.subtitle: The First Siege (1299-1307) and the Founding of Mansourah

paragraphs.text: A major conflict between the Marinids of Fez and Tlemcen began around 1295, initiating a period of Marinid aggression . Under Abu Said Othman ben Ya`qub, the Marinids besieged Tlemcen for eight years, from 1299 to 1307 . During this prolonged siege, the Marinid Sultan Abu Yacoub Youcef built the town of Mansourah near Tlemcen as a military camp to replace Tlemcen . The mosque of Mansourah was built around 1303 by Sultan Abu Yacoub . The siege impacted the city and its population, causing hardship . The poet Ibn Khamīs al-Tilimsānī fled Tlemcen in 1305 during the siege . He composed nostalgic poems called Tilimsāniyyāt while in exile . The siege was lifted in 1307 due to the assassination of the Marinid sultan .

sections.subtitle: Renewed Conflict and the Second Siege (1335-1337)

paragraphs.text: The Marinids returned under Sultan Abou al Hacen in 1335 and besieged Tlemcen, rebuilding Mansourah . This second major siege lasted from 1335 to 1337 . In 1337, after a two-year siege by Marinid sultan Abu-l-Hasan, Tlemcen fell under Marinid control for about ten years . Tlemcen was occupied by the Marinids from 1337 to 1348 . The Marinid rule installed in Tlemcen from 1337 favored the settlement of Hilalian Arabs north of Chlef, in contact with Ouarsenis .

During their rule, the Marinids enhanced the veneration of Sidi Bu Medien in Tlemcen, embellishing his mausoleum and adding the Al-'Ubbad mosque and a madrasa . The Mosque of Sidi Boumediene within the Tlemcen National Park was built in 1328 by Abu al-Hassan, a Marinid Sultan of Fes . Tlemcen's economy prospered under Marinid rule, benefiting from extensive trade, including Saharan trade .

Tlemcen was liberated in 1348 due to the Marinids' defeat in Tunisia . However, it fell to the Marinids again in 1352 under Abu Inan . During the second Marinid occupation (1352-1359), Abu Inan constructed the Sidi al-Halwi mosque, a madrasa, and a zawiya . Tlemcen returned to Abd al-Wadid control in 1359 after a revolt, marked by Hammū II's accession .

The Abd al-Wadid dynasty's weakened state led the Marinids to favor supporting Abd al-Wadid claimants over outright conquest . After 1389, the Abd al-Wadids lost military capabilities, becoming susceptible to Hafsid influence from Tunis by 1424 and beyond .

In the early 16th century, Aroudj Barbarossa conquered the kingdom of Tlemcen . The Spanish supported Bou-Hammou against the Barbarossas . Tlemcen was under siege, and Aroudj Barbarossa died during or after the siege . In the late period of the Abd al-Wadids, Tlemcen fell under Spanish (1509) and Turkish (1517) control multiple times before ultimately falling to Sa'adi and then Turkish forces in 1550 .

The constant conflict between the Marinids and Zayyanids is reflected in the construction of the Ya'qubiyya complex in Tlemcen in 1362–1363 by the Zayyanid sultan Abu Hammu Musa II . The complex was built to commemorate Zayyanid family members who fought against the Marinids . The ruins of Mansourah remain as a testament to the Marinid presence in the region .
